intro: Chthonocephalus oldfieldianus, commonly known as the ghost orchid, is a rare and elusive flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Orchidaceae family and is characterized by its lack of leaves, relying solely on its roots for photosynthesis. The plant typically grows on decaying wood, forming a symbiotic relationship with specific fungi to obtain nutrients. Its flowers are white or pale green, often appearing in clusters, and bloom during the late spring to early summer. Due to habitat loss and environmental changes, it is considered critically endangered and is protected in many regions.
